Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Polls stay open all day and the voter has a light schedule.
Story: I woke up early, the house already buzzing with excitement. My sister was making pancakes, and my parents were packing the car for our annual family trip to the lake—a tradition I’d never missed. As the oldest brother, I was expected to help organize, keep the younger kids entertained, and be present for every moment. But today was also Election Day. The polling station was open all day, and my schedule was light, so there was no excuse not to vote. My parents reminded me how important it was to be together, especially since my little brother had been looking forward to this trip for weeks. At the same time, I felt the weight of my civic duty pressing on me. I knew how much my vote mattered, and I didn’t want to let myself—or my community—down. As I loaded bags into the car, my mind raced, torn between the warmth of family expectations and the responsibility I felt as a voter. The clock ticked, and I could feel the pressure mounting, knowing I couldn’t be in two places at once.
